YKtgjkgmC6eaXyoscdakow.review_text: I always get weary about sushi boat type places as I've been to a couple of bad ones. I always see the same plates go by uneaten and with the occasional fly lingering around.  BF took me here just to look. I wanted to eat here right away since the fresh looking nigiri on the conveyor looked so yummy. Plus I love nigiri.  I got really excited and picked up two dishes right when we sat down. The fish on top of the rice was a good size. They took all of my requests from the menu because I didn't see them on the conveyor.   Service was prompt. They were so swift that I never noticed who came by each time and took the plastic lids. Also, in my opinion, the plastic lids kept the food clean.  I ate a lot. At times I had three plates in front of me. It's so easy to eat like a pig here. What I got...all nigiri.  *True Toro - That's what they called it. Soft and buttery and the marbling was nice. I ate three orders of this.  *Hotate - Pretty good. The scallops were a bit too cold though. I ate two orders of this.  *Albacore - Had some garlic on top and texture melted.  *Amaebi - Just okay. It was too cold and the kinda too bouncy in texture.  *Butterfish - Tried it and it's a pass for me. It was a bit rough.  *O-Toro - Not bad, although I liked the real tuna better.   Other things my bf got:  *California roll - Good...not much to say about a California roll.  *Tamago - Apparently super good since bf had like 5 plates of them.  *Salmon - Didn't try this.  I don't remember all of the things he ate since I was busy stuffing face. I shall come back. Too bad it's so far out of the way for me.

0nFJxhZ0cZ9K-GCsRQcYXg.review_text: By far our fav low key regular sushi. Consistent, delicious, friendly. Plus the $10 uni tray deal. Cheap fast fun dinner. Always come out happy. Don't change anything

U4Mos3ZeuUkb9ekQO7fbnQ.review_text: Your first question - I know it's coming so let's just get it over with - is how this place compares to Isobune, which I've visited 200+ times over the past 15 years. I asked myself that approximately every 15 seconds while having dinner at Tenroku last night.   I gave them both four stars, and I think they're very similar food quality-wise. You might even say they're kaitenical, and yes I do require an up vote if you got that.   I do like the atmosphere (the plating, the boat style, and just the general environment more) at Isobune. but this place didn't disappoint in the least.

xsIrsH98Vpf5v0ydv7gHkg.review_text: I wouldn't come back to this place. 2 stars instead of 1 because the servers were nice. Three other friends and I came in here for a birthday lunch and we weren't impressed.  Seating is only around the conveyor belt. Everything was expensive- our bill came out to $90 and we weren't even full. I would say each of us had an average of 5 plates but every plate you reach for adds up quickly and unexpectedly in price. Each plate starts at $2.00 (for example, edamame) up to $10 (for example, a plate of uni). I wouldn't mind pricey sushi if the fish were fresh and delicious but they weren't. Overall, nothing spectacular here and I would never crave this place. Definitely experienced better.

rP1JhMcc7sZTzW3KzLpL9w.review_text: This is a great spot for a quick sushi bite!  I personally don't have a gripe about japanese restaurants run by Chinese peeps, there are so many that it's hard to keep count. Heck, even the Japanese Tea Garden is filled with Chinese waitresses! That said, let's move onto the rest: - Good selection of fun american rolls as well as nigiri - Fish I've had has always been fresh  - Consistent service and food any day of the week - Friendly staff, tea constantly refilled without asking  It stacks pretty well against Isobune, which is only located on the other side of the bridge. The presentation is better, staff is nicer, seats aren't as crammed, and I prefer eating in a well-lit, clean environment with nice and clean floors. Prices aren't all that higher, so my preference has been to come to Tenroku instead. They have updated their price sheet to include a $2.5 black plate for tamago and edamame, as well as directions on what to do with all those lids.. please put them aside instead of back onto the conveyor belt (I think this comes after having too many pile-up accidents).  If you're trying to find it, it's across from the bookstore, right by the bridge, hard to miss!

TCim7E_XTZN6aahAsckbqg.review_text: tried this place for lunch..they are newly opened the service was not bad.they always check up on you and makes sure that you have everything you need. I wasnt so happy about the selection of the sushi well maybe because Im not a fan of sashimi's but it was ok.The price is reasonable unlike the other sushi boat in japantown lol

BdRMVROS1MXOHxr-bdZv0g.review_text: Definitely better than Isobune, the rotating boat place downstairs.  Price is good and place is clean(er).  Sushi isn't the freshest, but best for the price.  Come here if you are seeking value!  We only ordered 3 dishes from the conveyor:  1. Salmon avocado maki: good, decent 2. some sweet escargot/snail sushi. My caucasian boyfriend was curious. and described it as "chewy". I had to eat the rest of it -_- 3. Uni. I love uni. the coloring seemed a bit off but tasted great and a 2 huge pieces for $6  We ordered: - lobster tartare ($6. it wasn't entirely lobster - had roe and horseradish in it, but worth it) - sea bass steak ($12) - huge filet of seabass. also worth the money but had bones in it - chicken karaage ($6) - a bowl of fried chicken. delicious! - otoro, hamachi, and waru sashimi.  The waru was especially worthy it given the $3.5 price tag.  The otoro was decent, especially for $6.  Our total bill came out to $55 for 2.  Not bad for sushi and not bad for a total paleo meal!

D5uMny1pAVWhNGDvFDPp8g.review_text: I know conveyor/sushi boat is consisted quite gauche in some sushi loving circles but the 10 year old in me and the French Spouse loves the idea of endless options served immediately. Sadly what usually happens is you have low quality food or really basic rolls that are bland in taste.   Tenroku's sushi and maki are a step up in quality and taste than most kaiten places including Isobune just down the hall. Normally I would never get amiebi or uni at place like this but both were freshly made and of a good quality.  The space is smaller than most US kaiten places and they cover the plates which I like but some people might find annoying. Since it is a small place there probably wasn't as many dishes out but we never lacked in choices and the server was quick to take our order for anything that was out. The space is very clean and modern, there is one booth but the counter is bar height and not wheelchair accessible.  The prices range from 2-6 for most dishes which is actually lower than other places especially for the quality of the fish.  This is a place to taking the visiting mid-west relatives or get a quick bit before a movie at the Sundance theater.

h3yYR4rSvvNbrrTMCzSVrg.review_text: First time here. Tried this place because one of my friend don't eat raw fish but everyone else wanted sushi boat. Chinese owned. Everyone was speaking Cantonese. I liked the newly remodeled place. bright and clean (but maybe a little too bright). Little plastic covers over your sushi was a plus. We've been to places where we put sushi covers back on the conveyor belt. So my friend had placed her first cover back on the conveyor belt and happily continued on with our conversation. But then, we got cut off by the sushi man immediately. He removed it from the belt and asked her to leave it on her table next time; causing everyone to look at us like we're stupid. I understand each restaurant runs differently and we respect that. However, I wish they would have placed a sign or at least have the waitress instruct us on what to do with the plastic covers; instead of giving us the dirty look.   The fish there is okay. Some tasted fresh and some didn't. The uni and unagi is very good.  There was this one nigiri with seared white fish and ankimo on top; it tasted so bad i couldn't finish the rest. It did not taste like fish! Maybe because it was seared, it had a plastic taste to it. The fish tartar looked nice topped with caviar but the fish did not taste fresh. The green onions in it tasted as if it was chopped on an unwashed cut board, giving it an extra bit of unwanted flavor of ginger, garlic, and onions. The Tamago nigiri was a joke! Lots of fancy new sushi ideas. I usually like new ideas but some of these just did not tasted good. Just give me some "real" sushi please.  Overall, everything was ok. Most likely not returning. Sorry, but I rather go to Isobune...

qPJ5dUGFkdDrl2Kd0fvrlw.review_text: After a little shopping...decided to hit Japantown. All sushi and dishes ordered were great! Favorites were the ramen noodles and the deep fried squid legs. Angela was a very attentive and pleasant server! I look forward to returning!

IFJt9wsu9oKRSuVIhVMh2g.review_text: Great sushi, great entrees, and great service! Mandy, Carmen,and the entire staff are very friendly and accommodating!

Bf87HcPERF9yiSjb2tQBqw.review_text: Gah!   I saw all the four star reviews and thought, GREAT, fresh, well-made sushi.  Perfect quick nosh on a movie night with my Mr.  What I got was slightly clammy, untasty fish.  They seem to want to sell you fancy, over-amplified superrolls with cute names.  The table full of 20-somethings next to us had things on fire, things that smoked, and things with so many different kinds of stuff draped over them that they looked like some kind of science experiment gone bad.  Me, I just wanted some *real* sushi.  Some yellowtail, maybe a barbecued eel roll, some tekka maki, a kappa maki, sake nigiri.  All of the above were available (except the BBQ eel roll) but every one of them was overpriced and mediocre.  Clammy, not so fresh fish.  Tough nori on the rolls.  Doesn't anybody toast nori anymore?  The service was abrupt and dismissive and unfriendly.    IE.

BVKJF0OYYy9uqOEmEL37bw.review_text: food was tasty.  service was acceptable but what I really disliked was a bento box is around $10, and basically comes with a protein, rice, salad and a miso soup.  Nothing else.  Oh but if you want to, you can add things for $3 or $5 each!   WTF?  no thanks...I feel like this is the spirit airlines of restaurants.    The food didn't warrant the price.  I had the salmon bento with chicken Karaage, for $13.  Tiny portions and I left still hungry.

soFo2vPCPZey3F6XP4WATA.review_text: I'm not too fond of conveyer belt sushi, but this one was pretty decent. It's located in Japantown and never seem to have too much of a wait. Because it's conveyer belt sushi, food is served immediately! So it's a great option if you are dying of hunger at the moment.   Service:  The service here was nice and friendly. Not really attentive, but they are easy to flag down.   Food:  The food here is actually pretty good. Although, I wish they had more of a variety of sushi. Most of the options were pretty much one type of underlying sushi with a different topping or sauce on it. There were a couple of dishes that I particularly had a liking to - the one with the orange sauce on top. I don't know what it was, but would definitely recommend it.   But I have to admit this place is very reasonable priced and the quality is great.   Overall:  I would definitely recommend this place.

vIBqT6wJ-gNWKY-2vgBcmg.review_text: I'm a sashimi person and this is one of my go-to places for expensive cuts like Otoro. Most other places I had in downtown area before has great quality fish. But at over $10 fog two piece of Otoro is just little too much of a rip-off. Tenroku, though it is not super high-end quality Otoro every time, still beats the other places in terms of prices ($6!!!) and phatttt ass cut. On top of that, they still do a good job with the average stuff like anago sushi and spider-roll. And most if the time, their hamachi sashimi are fresh, thick, and cheap.   That's why I'm here all the time, and the 大将in the front middle is my amigo now lol. Dude is bro.

Z4R8BA-iGNwEtGsnfi7AEg.review_text: I totally don't understand why they have those plastic lids, but the servings are big and fresh.

bXc7_hewD5ledvVkaS4erg.review_text: A few words of advice: Manage your expectation.   If you're here for quantity consumed with disregards for the quality of the fish you are provided then you are golden. Paying $4.5/a pair of nigiri will get you full but that's different from getting you the satisfaction that you've enjoyed a good quality fish or sushi rice that is properly prepared. It's not great but it can get you full. Nothing more.   The postscript of my experience here is taking a peek at Isobune and realizing that the sushi on their boat is actually better looking.
